Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2013 02:57PM mia42 wrote: I think that being a nurse makes us more scared because we don't like to lose control (btw nurses tend to be control freaks LOL) and we have cared for people during times of debilitating illness--scary. I had needle localization and clip insertion during my biopsy but my surgery was not too bad--went in at 9am and was home by 5pm. The next step is where I am stuck and running out of time, I feel, to make a decision. My heart goes out to all of us dealing with this and I know that we can beat it!

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2013 04:55PM mia42 wrote: "Oncotype DX is a real-time RT-PCR assay measuring RNA expression in 16 cancer-related genes and five reference genes, using paraffin-embedded tissue. Results are given as a recurrence score between zero and 100, which are translated as low risk (a score of 18 or lower), medium risk (19 to 30), or high risk (31 or above). The MammaPrint microarray assay measures expression of 70 genes in fresh tissue; it categorizes patients as either high risk, with a so-called poor signature, or low risk (a so-called good signature) for recurrence. There is no intermediate category. Mammostrat is an immunohistochemistry test measuring five markers: p53, HTF9C, CEACAM5, NDRG1, and SLC7A5. The results are combined into a quantitative risk index: low, moderate, and high. For now, only MammaPrint has FDA clearance." This came fro an article on the College of American Pathologists website.http://www.cap.org/apps/cap.portaL?_nfpb=true&cntvwrPtlt_actionOverride=%2Fportlets%2FcontentViewer%2Fshow&_windowLabel=cntvwrPtlt&cntvwrPtlt%7BactionForm.contentReference%7D=cap_today%2F0611%2F0611a_testing_recurrence.html&_state=maximized&_pageLabel=cntvwr msmaples516--good luck with radiation! Let me know how it goes because it is in my immediate or possibly post-chemo future! You would not have qualified for the mammaprint study because you had a low Oncotype score and are node negative so that probably why you hadn't heard about it.

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2013 02:39PM mia42 wrote: Hello all, I am newly diagnosed and am at the point of making THE CHOICE!!!! After my mammogram, biopsy, and MRI, my BS and radiation onco were telling me I would not need chemo, but my MO has said chemo from day one. I wanted the lumpectomy because I knew it could be scheduled quickly, I knew from the MRI that I only had one lesion (breast feed two kids so no dense breast tissue here:), and I wanted this crap out of me. Walking around knowing it was there felt like I was in the alien movies with a malicious monster in me LOL! Initially after surgery, I thought I did not have any positive nodes but one node was positive for micromets less than .6mm of unorganized cells! It was like a gut punch! So again my MO is saying chemo until my Oncotype score came back as 9 i.e. low risk of reoccurence. I am now waiting on the results of my Mammoprint study which will score my tumor as low or high risk. I think that radiation will take care of the micromets but I still have a nagging feeling that I don't want to regret not having chemo if I should have a reoccurrence somewhere down the road. Trying to make this decision based on fact and not on fear or MO pressure. Has anyone else had the Oncotype testing? As a nurse, I do not believe in assembly line healthcare and agree with the posts that stress the importance of considering each person's case individually as it is unique. Sending out prayers for healing and positive energy to you all!
Posts.Title: Confused about recurrence possibility Mayanne ruthbru

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2013 04:35PM mia42 wrote: bdavis--Thank you for sharing your experience! My MO wants me to have 4 cycles of TC and just when I had about convinced myself that it was the thing to do, the Oncotype score comes back as low risk and I'm back at square one. How did you tolerate Tamoxifen? I am not looking forward to feeling like I'm in menopause and will consider have a hysterectomy with ovary removal as well but still undecided...arghhhhhh!
